job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Old Westbury, NY
pros: The hourly rate for adjuncts is the same as for full-time instructions, so the pay is good. Once hired, adjuncts can expect to finish a semester with little if any interference.
cons: Adjuncts get NO medical benefits. The first pay check each semester is usually significantly late. Although it is possible on paper to move up through the ranks from adjunct instructor to adjunct professor, no one ever tells an adjunct how to achieve that. Hiring of adjuncts is NOT on the basis of seniority.

job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in Old Westbury, NY
pros: If your personal background matches mine, employment here only serves as a "potboiler" job. In that event, the only "pro" is that it will help you pay for gas, electricity, etc.
cons: I was an Adjunct Assistant Professor of chemistry at NYIT / Old Westbury for twenty consecutive years until my retirement in June 2016. Too many in the NYIT community are mesmerized with hackneyed concepts such as "globalization", "diversity", and "Title IX compliance". Your potential issues as an employee? Suppose you are a Caucasian male, either Christian or Jewish, who believes in God and the free-market. Also, you are politically conservative, and are the descendant of a family that first arrived in the United States in the distant past. If the description above fits you and you are seriously considering accepting employment at NYIT, please do so with extreme circumspection. That's because if you do eventually work for NYIT and have this personal background, you may find that through no fault of your own, you have become "marginalized" and possibly even considered to be a "persona non grata".

review_title: A Rewarding and Trying Introduction to an Academic Career
job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: The benefits are solid; the students are generally eager to learn; and the administration is generally supportive of all research efforts, especially those with regards to educational and instructional technology. There is often a great deal of freedom for developing innovative curricula, depending on the department, of course.
cons:
As with many large colleges, the life of a tenure-track assistant professor is a busy one, and trying to balance 4 courses a semester with university service and substantial research can be trying. Often times, the requirements for tenure are ambiguous or unknown, and may change.

As for the students, the open admissions policy combined with a promise of quality training for employment gives a wide range of motivations and performance in the student body, and also may give them false hopes.

job_title: Manager in Old Westbury, NY
pros: Free undergraduate courses but you need an undergrad to get hired there. Graduate classes are free but they go against your yearly income and you get taxed.
cons:
The new teachers contract took away any good reason to stay, it eliminated the free medical benefits and the annual raises. The contract lasts 5 years and was just put into play Sept 2012
Some Departments are very very poorly run while others are run perfect
Once you are an employee the opportunity to move up is nonexistent
Very disorganized higher leadership, spending money like crazy and enrollment keeps level or falling, the ship is going down and no one seems to realize it except the people that cannot do anything to help it. 
Pay is very low at the lower levels and very high at the high levels

job_title: Adjunct Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: NYIT provides a good hourly pay (no benefits for adjuncts). My superiors are friendly, honest and young. I'm under the impression that they're doing their very best to provide a quality education to our students.
cons: I've experienced a constant lack of space and a lack of technical support. I was surprised that the NY Institute of Technology has a lot of malfunctioning equipment and only a few people who can make machines work. Some students are hostile and seem to have come exclusively for an international student visa and pay zero attention to their classes.

job_title: Administrative/Lab Assistant Midge Karr Building in Old Westbury, NY
pros:
Most people who work there are pleasant.

It is normally pretty quiet as most students and professors are working on things.

the Midge Karr Building where I worked is pretty relaxing.

some elitist and flaky professors that many people had issues with have retired or got replaced.
cons: there is old (10+ years old) hardware on the computers that they just updated

job_title: ELI Adjunct in New York, NY
pros:
Excellent facilities and research accessible. 
Perfect, central easy location for commuting. 
Nice area of the city to work in. 
The majority of the students are motivated and genuinely want to learn.
Feel safe on campus for the most part, but not protected under the HR regulations in all aspects. 
Security staff are polite and friendly and try to be helpful.
cons:
English Language Institute is run by two arrogant, uncaring, unprofessional Champagne Socialists, neither of whom have a background in English and who engineer courses to allow for gross cronyism, putting their friends in positions they are not qualified or experienced enough to deserve. 

Said in the interview they want teachers to be proactive and come forward with any concerns they have. When you do, they just ignore your emails or write back much later completely off-topic and in a condescending tone. They do not care about instructors being harassed or intimidated and will ignore any worries you may have, rewarding the perpetrator with extra responsibilities. 

Students get the short end of the stick at the end of the day and they don't know any better because the least qualified or experienced instructors are given preference and the most hours. They assign advance to people who can't spell 'attendance' and prefer to hire people who make a rebelWilson seen as classy as margotfonteyn. They'll push anyone with international experience well into the background so the loudmouths with connections can take over. 

Their hiring practices reveal their insecurity; they don't want to extend opportunities to anyone with extensive experience, because they themselves have very limited experience. I cannot understand how you get to be in charge of international students in an English department when your major is in German and you've never taught abroad. Definitely a case of not what you know, but who. 

They expect a commitment from you three months in advance but make absolutely no apology for changing the terms of the offer three days before the class begins, slashing your teaching hours by 75%. You will have turned down other employment opportunities in the interim, only to find yourself left with much left than was initially agreed upon. They don't have to say sorry or explain. 

The school supposedly has standards of academic integrity but makes half their classes online so the instructor is powerless to monitor students' behavior and so cheating is a big problem. 

If you take pride in your work, avoid this place at all costs. If you have created original material, it will be visible to all other instructors who will simply copy it from blackboard and use it in their classes passing it off as their own work. If you want to teach online (it's like asking a boxer to enter the ring with one arm tied behind his back) then just to Monroe. There's really zero difference in quality or the value placed on what instructors can bring to the faculty.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The hourly wage is high for my field, which is nice. The teaching materials and classroom facilities are also generally very good. Management has been pleasant to work with, and I have enjoyed teaching the students.
cons: Recent changes in my department have made my experience as an adjunct much more chaotic. Hours are very limited. It's virtually impossible to gain full-time work in my department.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Old Westbury, NY
pros: Decent Medical Benefits, Employees get tuition remission, decent looking campus, not far from where i live, some decent professors

job_title: Budget Manager in Old Westbury, NY
pros: Always busy - day goes fast and many nice associates to work with.  Free tuition for entire immediate family.

job_title: Driver in Old Westbury, NY
pros: Not a bad job if you can do a job and not complain. Management stays off your back if they know you can be reliable.
cons: Management always tries something new to make business better, but always end up going back to the same old routine. Sometimes have a disconnect between different management levels. Working hours can be early (4am) but you get out early. No room for advancement.

job_title: Support in Old Westbury, NY
pros: Medical Benefits, Team, Campus, Opportunity to work on both campuses (Manhattan and Old Westbury), International Presence, Academic Affairs staff are dedicated.
cons: Bad transportation services but driving my car took care of that.

review_title: It's Hard to Walk Tall When You're Small
job_title: ELI Instructor in New York, NY
pros:
The staff in the library are kind, friendly and helpful. 

The majority of students are respectful, motivated, fun to work with and appreciate that you know your stuff. 

Nice area of the city to work in. 

Fairly good facilities but not as much as you would expect from a college with that name.
cons:
Hiring team in ELI really don't care about you at all. There's a coldness, a callousness that exudes from both; it's either the arrogance of privilege or just their personality, but it most certainly does not make for a pleasant, supportive workplace. 

They're happy to hire people who can't spell but if you have more experience than the two of them combined, you get left at the bottom of the pile. So unfair. 

They're not student-centered, just career-centered. 

They say, "Here's my card, email if you have any questions" but when you do, they don't respond and just ignore you. There's an impatience, a definite meanness  in their attitude that makes them very unapproachable. It's almost like they hire you just to look down on you, but if you look up their professional background you realize it's nothing to boast about. Much of their behavior can be put down to jealously guarding their positions, insecure and threatened by anyone with a grain of intellect or more experience.

review_title: Pleasant experience working for the Engineering Department in Manhattan.
